div1.p: Reed's Birthplace will be Restored as a National Shrine

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, [The Washington Post], [November 14], 1926
div1.p:
REED'S BIRTHPLACE
WILL BE RESTORED
AS NATIONAL SHRINE

Movement to Purchase Hum-
ble Virginia Home Finally
Meets Success.

NATION'S DOCTORS HONOR
YELLOW FEVER MARTYR

Deed to Be Held by Medical
Society, Which Will Main-
tain Property.
BECOMES A NATIONAL SHRINE
BIRTHPLACE OF WALTER REED.
By DAISY ROWE HEVESSY.

Belroi, Va., Nov. 13.--The
humble two-room house here, in
which was born the late Walter
Reed, U. S. army surgeon, who be-
came famous for his discovery of
the cause of yellow fever, in which
investigation he sacrificed his life,
is to become a national shrine. The
movement, begun three years ago,
to restore the Reed home, has at
last been crowned with success. The
recent contribution of $1,000 from
the Virginia Medical association,
and an additional $500 from var-
ious groups, have made possible
the transfer of the title to the old
house and garden plot to the Wal-
ter Reed Medical society which be-
gan the movement. This organiza-
tion will take in hand the work of
restoring the old house and see
that it is maintained as a shrine.

Already the deed has been pre-
pared transferring cottage and
tract of land 100 by 220 feet from
its present owner, George D. Stubbs,
upon whose farm the old Reed
house has been used as tenant prop-
erty, to the Walter Reed Medical
society. This society is composed
of members scattered throughout
the United States who have been
cooperating with the Walter Reed
Memorial farm of the University of
Virginia.

Sufficient contributions covering
the purchase price are now in hand.
Future donations will be applied
to maintaining the property, which
is in Gloucester county, as a fitting
memorial to the famous surgeon.
Familiar to Motorists.

Familiar to motorists, this tiny
cottage near the Tidewater High-
way is about 160 miles from Wash-
ington, D. C. Before the door
stands the pink crepe myrtle tree,
planted years ago by the Rev. Lem-
uel Sutton Reed at the time he
served as pastor of Bellymus M.
E. church in Gloucester county.
Here in the old-time parsonage of
the circuit, Walter, his youngest
son, was born September 13, 1851.
Later the family moved to Harri-
sonburg, Va., where the children
of the preeacher received the best
schooling to be had under private
instruction at that time.

Later Walter Reed, in 1867, at-
tended two sessions at the Univer-
sity of Virginia, where he studied
Latin, Greek, English literature
and mathematics. In 1868 he
studied medicine, and at the end
of the session was graduated after
one year's work, giving evidence
that he was an exceptional student.
Following his graduation he went
to New York, and matriculated at
Bellevue Hospital Medical school.
A year later Walter Reed received
his M. D. degree. From Harvard
university he won his A. M. degree,
and the University of Michigan
later conferred upon him the LL. D.
degree. In 1893 he attended Johns
Hopkins university.
Worked Hard at Research.

From the time he was appointed
assistant surgeon in the army with
the rank of captain, on January
26, 1880, and subsequently surgeon,
with the rank of major, on Decem-
ber 4, 1893, to the time of his
death, on November 22, 1902, he
worked indefatigably in the field of
medical and bacteriological re-
search.

Dr. Reed's heroic experiments
while serving in the United States
army in Cuba to rid the island
of yellow fever are the outstanding
accomplishment of his life. He be-
lieved the mosquito was the trans-
mitter of the plague and to this
theory he clung tenaciously in his
determination to locate the guilty
agent. He found that no less than
700 separate species of tropical
mosquitoes exist.

After several years Walter
Reed's experiments were no longer
a mere theory, but were crowned
with success in ridding humanity of
the deadliest of diseases. Upon the
female stegomyia he placed and
proved responsibility for the havoc
wrought upon human lives.
Problem Became National One.

In 1898, when Dr. Gorgas be-
came chief sanitary officer for Cuba
the problem of ridding the terri-
tory of yellow fever became a na-
tional one. Centuries of Spanish
generations on this island knew no
hope or relief from the peril.

One outstanding man of those
years was Joseph L. Le Prince,
engineer, who was of great assist-
ance in making Havana sanitary.
The United States appointed the
yellow fever commission composed
of Walter Reed, James Carroll,
Jesse W. Legear and Aristides Ag-
ramonte. Names which now stand
high in scientific research and
heroism.

Dr. James Carroll permitted
himself to be bitten by an infected
stegomyia mosquito. He fell ill and
narrowly escaped death. He died
of a heart affection in 1907. Dr.
Legear died September 28, 1900.
A tablet to his memory at Johns
Hopkins hospital reads:

“With more than courage and
devotion of the soldier he risked
and lost his life to show how a
fearful pestilence is communicated
and how its ravages may be pre-
vented.”
Lauded by Gen. Wood.

But the memory of Maj. Walter
Reed, who learned the cause and
concerned himself with the control
of yellow fever is one which
“makes him great in the eyes of
science and greater in his service
to his fellow men.”

Gen. Leonard Wood, reflecting
on Reed's great achievement, said:
“I know of no man who has done
so much for humanity as Maj.
Reed. His discovery has resulted
in the saving of more lives annually
than were lost in the Cuban war,
and the saving for commercial in-
terests of the world of a sum
greater than the entire cost of the
Cuban war.”

The Walter Reed Memorial hos-
pital, occupying sixteen city blocks
at Washington, D. C., is the gift of
the Federal government and offers
specialized training to army offi-
cers besides caring for enlisted men
--a great tribute to the memory of
Reed.

The purchase of the humble
home in which Walter Reed was
born in this quiet corner of Vir-
ginia and its use as a shrine has
stirred the admiration and brought
support from medical men through-
out the world.
